block.p: On the Air, the Voice of Sunni Rebels in Iraq Images of attacks on American soldiers, along with scathing reports on Shiite militias and leaders, are beaming across Iraq 24 hours a day, broadcast by a banned TV station that is central to the Sunni insurgency.
PAGE 8
The Mayor and the Bullets Hours after Mayor Ernest Lampkins of Greenwood, La., said goodnight to his teenage daughter, two bullets paid a call. ''This Land,'' by Dan Barry.
PAGE 16

Don't Cut That Wire Cable operators like Comcast were once written off as doomed, with telephone companies and other providers seen as poised to dominate. But today cable suddenly looks like the winner.
SUNDAY BUSINESS
A Post-Abortion Syndrome? Anti-abortion activists say women are traumatized by abortions, and are trying to use this to reframe the abortion debate.
MAGAZINE
Turks Hold Suspect in Killing The Turkish police have arrested a teenage suspect in the death of a prominent newspaper editor who was shot Friday afternoon.
PAGE 4
Soul-Searching by Neighbors Residents of the town in Missouri where a boy was held for four years are asking themselves why no one noticed something amiss.
PAGE 25
The Triumph of Hollywood Foreign films win lots of awards, and indies are the darlings of the Sundance Film Festival, but Hollywood still rules.
ARTS & LEISURE
More Than It Hurts You A California assemblywoman plans to submit a bill that calls for up to a year in jail for parents who spank young children.
PAGE 16
The Mysteries of Kabul Gone are the days when backpackers made the Afghan capital a popular stop, but the city is attracting a new generation of travelers.
TRAVEL
